data.author: onsolidground
data.content: So 52p - 37p and a long hard look required 13th Jan 26. Results published + Presentation - SP rises to 52p. Presentation didn't seem to hit the right notes. Flash crash downwards. Positive sentiment turns to FUD. But lets recall; Positive media after and of 3 Brokers. One Broker upgraded quickly after (Jefferies) from 55p to 60p. Another maintained 80p guidance and Lastly JPM Cazenove reiterated a Target Price of 55p. No Sell recommendations. 22 Jan 26. Extra Bonus shares listed and admitted - 40,611,605 Many querying why these were awarded, after the the poor share price performance. No real share price reaction initially - but then it falls in the days after. Possible seller? 29th Jan 26. Linkedin post by Matt Moulding. Highlighting the current state of the UK market and querying when things will be addressed. Share price falls on the day and has fallen further today. Honest Injun - No rush of buyers either at just over 37p So much so that this is the case. THG Revenue.  £1.716 BILLION. Market Capitalisation: £579.49M Applied Nutrition (APN) Revenue. £107.1 MILLION Market Capitalisation: £582.5M But one, THG is generating  X 17 the revenue of APN. Significantly so. Virtually 6X also that on Nutrition. Sum of Parts of THG also far in excess. Yet they are actually valued less than APN. Then just to put things in perspective THG is actually being valued at less than the top end of the £400M to £600M speculative preliminary conditional offer that Selkirk Group made for THG Nutrition alone.  Meaning THG Beauty a £1.1 Billion Revenue generator consisting of multiple businesses and Brands is effectively valued for FREE. https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/SELK/response-to-statement-by-thg-plc-e3rw7vvgabgzb48.html Not wishing to be impertinent but yes you can blame the market but seriously any company you would expect also to look inward and to have a full scrum down, thorough review, dissection and implement improvement measures if necessary. For instance: Do we need to have Analyst meetings tagged to Trading updates when others don't bother. RNS Content the same - taking lessons out of others RNS with favourable reaction. Best practice. Might less be more. (See BOO, See APN and countless others). Participants if we do - do all contribute, are they media trained or media competent? Are these Linkedin postings actually benefiting group shareholders? Virtually every time these are posted then the share price goes down. Also why no Investor Relations engagement with shareholders. Might this not help resolve issues, FUD and misinformation. Then perhaps the biggest question. Is the share price ever going to recover to meaningful value and get out of this constancy of rise and fall with the present CEO, BoD, Strategy? Does it need a reshuffling or refreshing? My thoughts only. Enjoy your weekends.

data.author: onsolidground
data.content: Well either somebody is dumping shares or making damn sure they are lending them out in sufficient quantity to ensure a drop in the share price. Perhaps a disgruntled II? That, and no doubt helped along the way by those setting the price and those who benefit from churning volume, for incredibly the market price setting must have this now about Absolute Parity with APN in terms of Market Cap. The difference last night was only a mere £20 million. Absolutely astonishing really that both have similar market caps, when one (THG) generates £1.7Billion of Revenue against the others (APN) only just over £100 Million of Revenue, a difference of a Factor 17 - and THG has a Beauty division completely distinct from Nutrition and generating about £1.1 Billion revenues. Yes one might have Profit and the other not,  but then again one also has £55million sat in a pending  VAT refund, and the other probably hasn't. Just read the Linkedin post from last night and sorry to say it, but it's not how to win friends and influence people. That said  are you just meant to sit silent and watch whilst you're share price gets car crashed back and forward so some hedge fund or funds make £100's of millions through manipulation and by devaluing your share prices, - when the actual update actually read quite well. And was now over 2 weeks ago (13th Jan). Rightfully imo he does ask When? is something actually going to be done about this, as it's detrimental to the London Stock Exchange and AIM, with net withdrawals and no new listings. Maybe from a shareholder perspective, and years of this, you have to ask if this is being  targeted due to one or more Individuals at the top and actually in the longer term interests of shareholders is it not time to be looking at making some changes. Shame really for it was actually starting to look and trade like a FTSE 250 company, with a relatively stable share price and tight'ish range. Never moan though at the price that's presented to you. Might go cheaper still, might go higher. Staged entry always the better strategy imvho. Each decides their own respective strategy. Just my take on things.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Applied Nutrition v THG Nutrition 1 Comparing margins is meaningless. Applied Nutrition is a single-brand, wholesale-heavy, limited-SKU business. THG Nutrition is multi-brand, DTC-led, global, returns-heavy, and marketing-intensive. They do not have the same cost structure — whey price is only one input. You can’t isolate a margin gap and label it the Ingenuity tax. 2 Related-party payments are not theft — they’re disclosed, audited, and priced under transfer-pricing rules The MSA was approved by the board, reviewed by auditors, and disclosed in full. If fees were inflated, auditors and regulators would not allow them. Related-party transactions,  value extraction — they exist in almost every demerged structure. 3 The tech wasn’t given away, Ingenuity was moved so it could be valued, sold, or partnered independently. That’s exactly what investors had been demanding for years. THG still has full contractual access — nothing was lost. 4 Debt staying with RemainCo is normal in demergers Debt follows cash-generating businesses (Nutrition & Beauty). That’s standard corporate finance, not a dump. Bottom line: There is zero evidence of theft, only a standard demerger structure that the market may or may not like.  If this were a screw job, it would not have been signed off on by the auditors, regulators, banks, and major shareholders. Without actual proof, this is noise with an agenda. The share price is being manipulated of that there is no doubt. Everybody knows it.

data.author: cantbelieveit
data.content: PROOF #4: The "Headcount" Shuffle The Document: THG Annual Report (Strategic Report Section - People). The Test: Are you paying for ghost workers? Look at the "Average number of employees" note. The Trend: You will likely see the headcount at THG Public drop significantly (as tech/warehouse staff moved to Ingenuity). The "Screw Job": Even though the staff are gone, the "Distribution Costs" line item on the Income Statement didn't drop by the same amount. Instead, the cost just changed names from "Wages" to "Service Fees." You are paying the same (or more) for staff you no longer employ or control. Summary: The Single Chart to Look For If you only look at one thing, find the "Segmental Adjusted EBITDA" chart in the H1 2025 presentation. Visual Proof: You will see a bar for THG Nutrition that is tiny compared to 2 years ago. Ask yourself: "Did people stop eating protein?" No (see Applied Nutrition). "Did the warehouse get more expensive?" Yes.

data.author: cantbelieveit
data.content: You don't have to trust me, and you don't have to trust Matthew Moulding. You can see the "screw job" yourself by looking at three specific public documents. Here is your "Do It Yourself" Audit Kit to prove THG Public (You) is being drained by Ingenuity Private (Moulding). PROOF #1: The "Same Ingredients, Different Profit" Test The Document: THG Interim Results H1 2025 (Released Sept 2025) vs. Applied Nutrition FY25 Results (Released Nov 2025). The Test: Both companies buy the exact same raw material (Whey Protein). Both sell to the same customers. Go to THG’s H1 2025 Report: Look for the Segmental Breakdown table. Find: THG Nutrition Adjusted EBITDA Margin. The Number: You will see it collapsed to ~3.9%. (Management blamed "high whey prices"). Go to Applied Nutrition’s FY25 Report: Look for the Financial Highlights page. Find: EBITDA Margin. The Number: You will see it sits at ~30%. The Conclusion: If "high whey prices" were the real problem, Applied Nutrition would have crashed too. They didn't. The ~26% difference is almost entirely the "Ingenuity Tax"—the inflated fees THG Nutrition is forced to pay for warehousing and tech. PROOF #2: The "Related Party" Leak The Document: THG Demerger Circular (Published Nov 2024) or the H1 2025 Financial Statements. The Test: Find the money leaving the building. Go to the "Related Party Transactions" Note: This is usually Note 18 or similar in the back of the accounts. Find: "Amounts payable to THG Ingenuity." The Number: In 2024/2025, this figure runs into the hundreds of millions. The "Kick in the Teeth": Look for the "Master Services Agreement (MSA)" terms in the Demerger Circular. It explicitly states the contract is for 10 years. This proves you are legally locked into paying these fees until ~2035, regardless of whether you make a profit. PROOF #3: The "Debt Dump" The Document: THG H1 2025 Balance Sheet. The Test: Who kept the mortgage, and who got the house? Look at "Net Debt": You will see THG Public (RemainCo) holds roughly £321 million in net debt. Look at "Intangible Assets": You will see a massive drop because the proprietary technology (the "Ingenuity Platform" IP) was transferred to the Private Company. The Conclusion: The Public Company kept the debt (the burden) but gave away the tech assets (the potential growth). You are now paying rent to use the technology you used to own, while still paying off the bank loans used to build it.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: This is what MM said - he is open to selling assets, and I think he will. Look, as you would expect, since we’ve announced the sale of Claremont, there’s obviously a lot of interest in the background as to some of our other manufacturing assets in particular and the performances of that. It would be fair to say we’ve had formal approaches on some of those assets. We’re pretty clear as to how we stand on these things, which is the private market valuations, as we saw with Claremont, are robust. If we receive interest in an asset where we believe we can make a deal work for us without in any way negatively impacting the existing business models of either nutrition or beauty, then sure, we will entertain that and know and derive a fair valuation for one of those assets, especially if it’s of a material value. If it’s something that’s like with Claremont, it was £100 million plus consideration, then sure, we would do that, especially given the valuations that are on, you know, of THG and the wider PLC market today. I think that’s probably as deep as I should go into that. I think we’ve been pretty frank and open to say, look, we could quite readily put an RNS out at any point to say we’ve done a transaction. It would be something that’s relatively non-core at a fair market value that delivers something that we’re pretty pleased with. How long will that be before we do that? Who knows? It will depend on achieving the right price points, if those prices arrive. That’s probably as much as I can say right now.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Am with John Gould on how undervalued THG is; let's not forget what he said a few months ago Coke has a market cap of £211bn and small net debt with £35bn of sales giving an EV/Sales of 6.6x. Coke backed Monster ten years ago with a $2bn investment for a 17% holding. That $2bn represented less than 1% of Coke’s value. Monster has revenues of £5.6bn, a market cap of £48.1bn with small debt giving an EV/Sales of 8.6x. Monster’s share price is up 40x over 20 years. Coke’s $2bn investment is now worth around $8bn, driven by Monster’s push through Coke’s distribution network. Celsius, the US-listed health drink, offers a similar story. Pepsi is an 11% shareholder and global distribution partner. Pepsi bought into Celsius in 2022 and in August 2025 with another $500m. Pepsi has invested over $1bn for its 11% stake which is less than 1% of its mkt cap. Celsius’s mkt cap is £11.1bn with revenue of £1.0bn last year being an 11x sales multiple. Its share price is up c.30x in just five years. Lotus Bakeries, the Dutch-listed food business behind Lotus Biscoff, shows that you don’t need to be Coke-sized to achieve strong valuations. Its health division includes Trek and Nak’d bars, both acquired over the past five years. Lotus has a mkt cap of £5.7bn with small debt with £1.1bn revenue in 2024 and trades on an EV/Sales of 5.4x. Fevertree, a UK stock partnered with Molson in January 2025 which invested £70m for an 8.5% stake (around 1% of Molson’s mkt cap). Fevertree has sales of £360m last year and a mkt cap of £1bn, giving EV/Sales of 2.7x. Molson has the capability to significantly accelerate Fevertree’s growth. As for THG, its mkt cap is £540m with £200m net debt, giving an EV of £740m. Total sales post-demerger last year were £1.7bn, of which £580m came from THG Nutrition (MyProtein) and the balance from THG Beauty. If we split value 50/50, MyProtein trades on c. 0.6x sales. MyProtein appears to be on the radar screen of several global brands such as Muller and the new unnamed global confectioner who appear to want to work with them on product development.

data.author: onsolidground
data.content: Hype, nobody will ever know the KPI's that the LTIP were linked to as they rarely publish them, and some individuals KPI's may have been linked to ESG and say tree planting as opposed to those creating shareholder value. A look at the chart though shows that just about the time the LTIP options were granted in 2022 the share price had fallen off a cliff from 700p and was sat somewhere between 200p and 100p approx. data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Protein powders are not automatically HSA/FSA-eligible under normal IRS rules. My earlier wording made it sound like they’re universally covered, which isn’t accurate. What’s actually happening with the Myprotein + Flex partnership is this: Standard IRS rules only allow HSA/FSA spending on items that treat or prevent a specific medical condition. General “wellness” protein or supplements for fitness don’t qualify by default. Platforms like Flex/TrueMed work by: Screening the customer with a short health questionnaire Determining whether the product is being used for a medical purpose (e.g., obesity management, malnutrition, recovery, doctor-recommended use) Generating the required documentation/Letter of Medical Necessity Then enabling HSA/FSA payment at checkout when it meets those criteria. So it’s new in the sense that:

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: OK so I have no clue what an FSA or HSA is so I googled it: HSA (Health Savings Account) and FSA (Flexible Spending Account) are U.S. schemes that let people pay for health-related products with pre-tax dollars, effectively giving a 20–40% saving depending on tax bracket. An HSA is linked to a high-deductible health plan and the money belongs to the individual forever, rolling over year to year and even earning investment growth. An FSA is provided by employers, also tax-free, but usually must be used within the year with limited rollover. Both can be used for eligible medical and wellness items, and with partners like Flex they can now cover products such as protein powders and creatine, making those purchases significantly cheaper for U.S. consumers.

data.author: gggg21
data.content: Potentially tapped a larger market in USA now as spend can be at myprotein in US A Flexible Spending Account (FSA) in the USA is an employer-sponsored, tax-advantaged account that allows employees to set aside a portion of their earnings to pay for eligible medical, dental, vision, or dependent care expenses. Because the money is deducted from paychecks before taxes are taken out, it lowers taxable income, typically resulting in a savings of about 30% on eligible expenses. Key Types of FSAs Health Care FSA (HCFSA): Used for qualified medical, dental, and vision expenses, such as copayments, deductibles, prescription drugs, and medical devices (e.g., crutches, blood sugar test kits). Limited Expense Health Care FSA (LEX HCFSA): Designed for those with a High Deductible Health Plan (HDHP) and a Health Savings Account (HSA). It only covers dental and vision expenses, helping preserve HSA funds. Dependent Care FSA (DCFSA): Used to pay for qualified out-of-pocket dependent care expenses, such as preschool, summer day camp, before/after-school programs, and child/adult daycare, allowing employees to work. Rules and Limitations Contribution Limits (2026): For 2026, the maximum contribution to a health care FSA is $3,400 per year. The maximum for a dependent care FSA is $7,500 per household, or $3,750 if married and filing separately. "Use-It-or-Lose-It": Unused funds are generally forfeited to the employer at the end of the plan year.

data.author: Craftyinvestor

As of the end of 2024, over 59 million Americans are covered by an HSA, with around 39 million individual HSA accounts in use — and that number has been growing steadily year-on-year. That means a substantial audience with pre-tax spending power on health and wellness products, which can boost repeat purchases and increase average order size for Myprotein. More people being able to use their HSA dollars for protein, creatine and other nutrition stacks could translate into meaningful sales growth.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Rock, I don’t think that’s realistic. This wasn’t just an internal “transfer pricing” exercise done in a back room – the demerger was a major corporate transaction with lenders, auditors and institutional shareholders all having a direct financial interest in the outcome. The banks refinancing THG wouldn’t have signed off contracts that left remainco carrying uncommercial terms, and the auditors have to be comfortable that related-party arrangements are on arm’s-length terms. Large shareholders didn’t just shrug and hope for the best either. They had every incentive to challenge anything that disadvantaged THG remainco, because they’re the ones whose value would be destroyed if the contracts were unfair. The idea that the business was carved up with no meaningful scrutiny doesn’t stack up with how these processes actually work in listed companies. Could the terms have been negotiated harder? Maybe – but to suggest they’re obviously “bad deals” assumes everyone involved ignored their own interests, which seems far less likely than the contracts being broadly commercial and workable for both sides.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Monty, I totally get your point about looking at PAT vs debt — that’s exactly why the THG picture is improving. Net debt has already been coming down materially. The recent Claremont sale alone brought in around £100m+ in cash, with proceeds directed to further deleveraging. On top of the earlier refinancing and disposals, THG has taken hundreds of millions off gross debt over the last 18 months, which directly reduces interest costs and improves the PAT outlook. That’s why analysts are now pointing to 2026 as the year THG reports its first genuine net profit. Lower finance charges + improving EBITDA from Nutrition and Beauty = PAT finally turning positive. This isn’t “window dressing,” it’s basic mechanics: less debt = less interest = more profit flowing to the bottom line. Also worth remembering THG still has significant assets. We know there is a lot of interest in many of these assets. Another strategic sale or minority stake in one of the premium brands could realistically wipe the debt altogether. If that happened, PAT would step up sharply because the interest burden would almost disappear. So when you talk about a sensible debt/PAT ratio, that’s exactly the path that THG is on — deleveraging first, profitability second. data.author: stanleyb
data.content: This is what an AI engine thinks of any Potential partnership deal between THG and Greggs if it were to happen..quite interesting read. JAO 😳 😳 Here is why a THG (Myprotein) x Greggs partnership would—theoretically—be a brilliant financial move for both: ​1. The "Health-Halo" for Greggs ​Greggs is currently desperate to prove it isn't just a "sausage roll peddler." ​The Problem: Their "Balanced Choice" range has been around for years, but it lacks "street cred" with the fitness crowd. ​The Solution: A Myprotein-branded "Power Meal Deal" at Greggs would give them instant authority. Imagine a "Myprotein x Greggs" Chicken & Pesto Pasta or a high-protein breakfast pot. It would turn a "guilty pleasure" destination into a legitimate choice for the 14% of UK consumers currently trying to increase protein intake. ​2. Physical Footprint for THG ​THG has roughly 2,700 "doors" via its recent Sainsbury’s/Greencore deal. ​The Scale: Greggs has over 2,740 shops and is aiming for 3,000. ​The Advantage: A Greggs partnership would effectively double Myprotein’s physical presence overnight. More importantly, it puts Myprotein in high-footfall "grab-and-go" locations (train stations, high streets, and petrol stations) where people are looking for a quick, healthy alternative to a pasty. ​3. Fighting the "GLP-1" Decline ​Greggs' CEO, Roisin Currie, admitted in late 2025 that appetite-suppressing drugs are a "market headwind." ​People on these medications eat less, but when they do eat, they prioritize nutrient density (protein/fibre) to avoid muscle loss. ​By partnering with Myprotein, Greggs could capture the "reduced-appetite" spender who is currently walking past their store to go to an M&S Foodhall or a Joe & The Juice. ​Is it actually likely? ​While it makes financial sense, there are two major hurdles: ​The Brand Conflict: Greggs has spent 10 years building its own "Balanced Choice" brand. Admitting they need Myprotein's help might be seen as a sign of weakness by their own marketing team. ​The Greencore Exclusive: It’s possible that THG’s new deal with Greencore (who also supplies many of the UK's top retailers) might have "exclusivity clauses" that prevent Myprotein from doing a direct manufacturing deal with a competitor like Greggs for a set period. ​Summary: The "Bull Case" for the Share Price ​If Matt Moulding announced a Greggs x Myprotein partnership, the share price would almost certainly re-test that 51p level or higher. It would be seen as the ultimate "mainstreaming" of the brand. JAO ADYOR!

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Positive feedback on the partnership 1. A powerful strategic fit Greencore Group plc is one of the UK’s and Ireland’s largest convenience food producers — supplying sandwiches, wraps, ready meals and other chilled products. It’s also the largest sandwich manufacturer in the world. So partnering with them gives Myprotein instant credibility and best-in-class manufacturing, distribution and category expertise. For Greencore, working with the UK’s biggest sports nutrition brand positions them at the heart of the high-growth, high-protein convenience market rather than just traditional sandwiches. 2. Major retail validation Launching in 500+ Sainsbury’s stores and inside the meal deal space is a huge achievement. Meal deals drive some of the highest footfall and repeat purchase in UK grocery — this puts Myprotein in front of millions of mainstream consumers, not just gym enthusiasts. 3. Category expansion done the right way Moving from powders and supplements into fresh, ready-to-eat food is a bold step. Doing it via Greencore shows a smart, asset-light strategy: leverage an expert partner instead of building complex chilled manufacturing in-house. 4. Products that match consumer trends Up to 28g protein, <376 calories, strong flavours like Firecracker and Teriyaki — this hits exactly what shoppers want: Healthier Convenience, High protein,Great taste with no “diet food” compromise Perfect for the growing audience of hybrid workers and time-poor consumers. 5. Growth runway for both sides The post confirms this is just phase one, with broader UK distribution planned later in the year. That gives Greencore: incremental volumes,higher-value branded production, deeper relationship with THG/Myprotein And gives Myprotein a bridge from online dominance into offline everyday consumption.. Well done, THG this is a great deal

data.author: sparsam
data.content: Ok and here are all your points with a bearish view. THG Q4 Earnings Call “Strong Return to Growth” – Or Just Easy Comparatives? •	The 7% Q4 growth is viewed by critics as largely a function of easy prior-year comparisons, following multiple years of contraction rather than a true acceleration. •	Forum users note that management has repeatedly talked up “strong H2 momentum” in previous years, only for growth to fade again. •	The claim that H2 came 14% ahead of guidance is treated with scepticism, as THG has a long history of guidance resets, lowered bars, and selective framing. •	“Broad-based growth” is questioned, with bears arguing that growth is uneven and still dependent on promotions and discounting, not organic demand strength. ⸻ Beauty “Exceptional” – But at What Cost? •	The 6.4% Q4 beauty growth is seen as underwhelming relative to the amount of marketing spend and discounting required to achieve it. •	Critics on LSE highlight that growth in Lookfantastic UK & Ireland (+16.2%) likely reflects: •	Heavy promotional activity •	Loyalty incentives that compress margins •	Pull-forward demand rather than sustainable expansion •	Record retention and higher spend per customer are viewed cautiously, with posters noting: •	Loyalty schemes often mask churn by subsidising repeat purchases •	Increased spend may be inflation-driven, not volume-led •	TikTok and social-driven trends are considered highly fickle, with little moat and rapid reversals in consumer behaviour. ⸻ Offline Beauty Stores – High Risk, Low Proof •	The Altrincham store being “ahead of expectations” is dismissed by sceptics as: •	A single data point •	Located in an affluent catchment area unlikely to be representative •	Profitability claims are questioned due to: •	Lack of disclosed store-level economics •	No clarity on rent, staffing, or capex assumptions •	The so-called “halo effect” is viewed as unquantified marketing spin, something THG has frequently cited without hard evidence. •	Bears argue store expansion introduces: •	Fixed costs •	Execution risk •	A move away from the asset-light e-commerce model THG once sold investors ⸻ Nutrition Growth – Margin Pressure Still the Elephant in the Room •	8.5% Q4 growth in Nutrition is viewed as modest given the category’s historical growth rates. •	Claims of Myprotein being the “world’s number one” brand are criticised as: •	Marketing language without independently verifiable metrics •	US retail listings (GNC, Kroger) are seen as: •	Lower-margin wholesale channels •	Likely to dilute brand positioning and profitability •	Elevated whey prices are not dismissed as “temporary” by critics, who argue: •	Structural protein demand + geopolitics = permanently higher input costs •	THG lacks sufficient pricing power to fully pass these through •	Activewear growth is viewed as: •	A crowded, low-loyalty category •	Historically poor margin territory for DTC bran

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Instead of singing about the last quarter, let's post it: Summary of THG Q4 Earnings Call THG Holdings PLC delivered a strong Q4 and ended 2025 with clear momentum, marking its first full year of revenue growth since 2021 despite a challenging macro backdrop. Strong Return to Growth * Q4 revenue grew 7%, driven by a very strong second half. * H2 performance came in **14% ahead of the top end of guidance, highlighting improving execution. * Growth was broad-based across core divisions. Beauty Performing Exceptionally Well * THG Beauty grew 6.4% in Q4, well ahead of expectations. * Lookfantastic UK & Ireland delivered **16.2% growth**, supported by: * Record customer retention * Growing loyalty membership * Higher spend per customer * Management highlighted strong momentum in devices, apps, loyalty schemes and social-driven beauty trends (including TikTok influence). Offline beauty is also proving successful: * The first Lookfantastic store in Altrincham has traded significantly ahead of expectations. * The store is profitable **and** delivering a measurable online “halo effect”. * Additional stores are planned, using a disciplined, brand-partnered rollout strategy. Nutrition Continues to Grow * THG Nutrition grew 8.5% in Q4. * Myprotein remains the world’s number one sports nutrition brand. * Offline expansion continues, with new U.S. listings at major retailers including GNC and Kroger launching in H1 2026. While whey prices remain elevated, management stressed: * Global protein demand is at record levels * Commodity cycles are temporary * The long-term market opportunity has significantly expanded High-margin categories such as activewear are growing strongly and are expected to exceed **15% of Myprotein revenue mix in 2026**. Business Simplification Largely Complete * Portfolio optimisation in beauty (exiting lower-return regions) is now largely annualised. * Non-core asset disposals and operational streamlining are complete. * This sets up **cleaner comparisons and improved efficiency** going into 2026. Confident Outlook for 2026 Management repeatedly emphasized confidence in trading momentum: * Expected **FY26 EBITDA around £100m** * Forecast **£20–25m of free cash flow** * Continued investment in marketing to support sustainable long-term growth * Increased use of AI and personalization tools across beauty CEO Matthew Moulding stated the group enters 2026 with significant momentum and a stronger, more focused operating model. VAT Upside Optionality * THG is awaiting the outcome of HMRC’s final appeal attempt. * Potential VAT repayment has grown to approximately £55m. * Management has taken a prudent approach, continuing to pay VAT while the case concludes. * Any successful outcome would represent a material cash inflow for the group.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Positive feedback on the partnership 1. A powerful strategic fit Greencore Group plc is one of the UK’s and Ireland’s largest convenience food producers — supplying sandwiches, wraps, ready meals and other chilled products. It’s also the largest sandwich manufacturer in the world. So partnering with them gives Myprotein instant credibility and best-in-class manufacturing, distribution and category expertise. For Greencore, working with the UK’s biggest sports nutrition brand positions them at the heart of the high-growth, high-protein convenience market rather than just traditional sandwiches. 2. Major retail validation Launching in 500+ Sainsbury’s stores and inside the meal deal space is a huge achievement. Meal deals drive some of the highest footfall and repeat purchase in UK grocery — this puts Myprotein in front of millions of mainstream consumers, not just gym enthusiasts. 3. Category expansion done the right way Moving from powders and supplements into fresh, ready-to-eat food is a bold step. Doing it via Greencore shows a smart, asset-light strategy: leverage an expert partner instead of building complex chilled manufacturing in-house. 4. Products that match consumer trends Up to 28g protein, <376 calories, strong flavours like Firecracker and Teriyaki — this hits exactly what shoppers want: Healthier Convenience, High protein,Great taste with no “diet food” compromise Perfect for the growing audience of hybrid workers and time-poor consumers. 5. Growth runway for both sides The post confirms this is just phase one, with broader UK distribution planned later in the year. That gives Greencore: incremental volumes,higher-value branded production, deeper relationship with THG/Myprotein And gives Myprotein a bridge from online dominance into offline everyday consumption.. Well done, THG this is a great deal

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Greencore is the new MyProtein food to go partner :) Myprotein 84,618 followers Elevating lunchtime with our latest launch Our new range of protein wraps and salads is now available in over 500 Sainsbury's stores, delivered through a strategic partnership with Greencore, the market leader in food-to-go. This marks a key milestone for the brand as we expand into a new category and make high-quality, high-protein options more accessible within the meal deal space, Executed exclusively with Sainsbury's, this launch lays the foundations for broader UK distribution later this year. We're initially launching with two wraps, Firecracker Chicken and Teriyaki Chicken, alongside a Greek Chicken Salad, delivering up to 28g of protein and less than 376 calories. Maximum quality, with no compromise on taste. If you've forgotten your meal prep, get yourself down to Sainsbury's to give these a go.

data.content: Stan, you’re trying to compare two businesses that are structured in completely different ways. APN is a focused retailer with a narrow product set, whereas THG is an integrated global platform that is home to 2 powerhouses: Beauty & Nutrition. Lumping all of THG’s £1.7bn revenue against APN’s £105m and expecting the same margin profile simply isn’t a like-for-like comparison. Over £1.1bn of THG revenue comes from Beauty, a category with very different margin dynamics to protein powders, and nothing to do with whey input costs. THG also owns assets APN doesn’t. Capex has already fallen sharply post-demerger and net debt is down materially, which shows the model is moving in the right direction. APN making £30m on £105m sales is great, but it operates a far simpler model with far less infrastructure. THG is building a global brand and that inevitably distorts short-term P&L versus a pure retailer. As cash flow turns positive in 2026, the operating leverage will start to show. An audit wouldn’t magically strip out £150m – most of those costs support owned assets and capabilities APN simply doesn’t have. Compare the right segments on a like-for-like basis and the picture looks very different. And guess what -  MyProtein in its infancy was making £30M on £100M revenue Lastly, what happened to 'It's not THG's fault, it's the fault of the Hedge Funds' we had 100s of those posts from you last year - have you flipped :) Stanleyb Posted in: THG Posts: 3,836 Fines, fines, fines...28 Oct 2025 10:24 Fines, fines, fines..!!! Is THG yet another victim of Fugazi and FUD???? Adyor! https://www.reuters.com/article/business/moodys-pays-864-million-to-us-states-over-pre-crisis-ratings-idUSKBN14X2LP/ https://www.rttnews.com/3472794/sec-fines-moody-s-s-p-other-credit-rating-agencies-over-recordkeeping-failures.aspx https://www.esma.europa.eu/press-news/esma-news/esma-fines-moody%E2%80%99s-%E2%82%AC37-million-conflicts-interest-failures https://www.whitecase.com/insight-alert/doj-sec-bring-enforcement-actions-against-short-sellers-highlighting-continued https://www.moneylaunderingnews.com/2020/07/leaked-fbi-report-reveals-private-equity-under-enhanced-money-laundering-scrutiny/ https://share.google/TQxFKqhcpdU8LW0pB https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/articles/cp9z332j4npo.amp

data.author: stanleyb
data.content: ​This is what AI says..... 1. Highly Profitable (The "Paper" Success) ​Profitability is an accounting metric. It’s what is left over after you subtract expenses from revenue. When a company is "highly profitable," its margins are excellent—it earns a lot of money for every dollar it spends. ​2. Cash Generative (The "Wallet" Success) ​Cash generation (often called Free Cash Flow) refers to the actual physical money moving into the company’s bank account. A "cash generative" business is one that consistently produces more liquid cash than it spends to keep the doors open. Adyor!!!!

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: For those who missed it, and seeing as how Dermstore is being discussed: THG originally acquired Dermstore for approx. £260 million in late 2020 from Target Corporation. At that time, the deal was at roughly 1.8× forward revenue and added significant US beauty sales to THG’s portfolio. Given that Dermstore has probably grown its revenue and profit since it was purchased, a buyer is likely to pay a higher valuation multiple than what Target did, especially if Dermstore is now more profitable or has stronger market positioning. Link to strong market positioning: https://www.linkedin.com/posts/wearethg_wearethg-activity-7422688274114072576-uv3b/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=member_android&rcm=ACoAADGjivYBi98_Kr0ghVvJn-kmg4bPEKZKahI Online beauty and skincare marketplaces can trade at high revenue multiples (depending on growth/EBITDA), often in the 1.5×–3× revenue range if earnings are robust and predictable. If they did sell Dermstore, a conservative price would be £350 to £500M. And here is the crazy thing, if it sold at the upper end of £500M then that is not that far from the current MC

data.author: onsolidground
data.content: So 52p - 37p and a long hard look required 13th Jan 26. Results published + Presentation - SP rises to 52p. Presentation didn't seem to hit the right notes. Flash crash downwards. Positive sentiment turns to FUD. But lets recall; Positive media after and of 3 Brokers. One Broker upgraded quickly after (Jefferies) from 55p to 60p. Another maintained 80p guidance and Lastly JPM Cazenove reiterated a Target Price of 55p. No Sell recommendations. 22 Jan 26. Extra Bonus shares listed and admitted - 40,611,605 Many querying why these were awarded, after the the poor share price performance. No real share price reaction initially - but then it falls in the days after. Possible seller? 29th Jan 26. Linkedin post by Matt Moulding. Highlighting the current state of the UK market and querying when things will be addressed. Share price falls on the day and has fallen further today. Honest Injun - No rush of buyers either at just over 37p So much so that this is the case. THG Revenue.  £1.716 BILLION. Market Capitalisation: £579.49M Applied Nutrition (APN) Revenue. £107.1 MILLION Market Capitalisation: £582.5M But one, THG is generating  X 17 the revenue of APN. Significantly so. Virtually 6X also that on Nutrition. Sum of Parts of THG also far in excess. Yet they are actually valued less than APN. Then just to put things in perspective THG is actually being valued at less than the top end of the £400M to £600M speculative preliminary conditional offer that Selkirk Group made for THG Nutrition alone.  Meaning THG Beauty a £1.1 Billion Revenue generator consisting of multiple businesses and Brands is effectively valued for FREE. https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/SELK/response-to-statement-by-thg-plc-e3rw7vvgabgzb48.html Not wishing to be impertinent but yes you can blame the market but seriously any company you would expect also to look inward and to have a full scrum down, thorough review, dissection and implement improvement measures if necessary. For instance: Do we need to have Analyst meetings tagged to Trading updates when others don't bother. RNS Content the same - taking lessons out of others RNS with favourable reaction. Best practice. Might less be more. (See BOO, See APN and countless others). Participants if we do - do all contribute, are they media trained or media competent? Are these Linkedin postings actually benefiting group shareholders? Virtually every time these are posted then the share price goes down. Also why no Investor Relations engagement with shareholders. Might this not help resolve issues, FUD and misinformation. Then perhaps the biggest question. Is the share price ever going to recover to meaningful value and get out of this constancy of rise and fall with the present CEO, BoD, Strategy? Does it need a reshuffling or refreshing? My thoughts only. Enjoy your weekends.
data.thread_title: A Weekend of Reflection for the BoD

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Applied Nutrition v THG Nutrition 1 Comparing margins is meaningless. Applied Nutrition is a single-brand, wholesale-heavy, limited-SKU business. THG Nutrition is multi-brand, DTC-led, global, returns-heavy, and marketing-intensive. They do not have the same cost structure — whey price is only one input. You can’t isolate a margin gap and label it the Ingenuity tax. 2 Related-party payments are not theft — they’re disclosed, audited, and priced under transfer-pricing rules The MSA was approved by the board, reviewed by auditors, and disclosed in full. If fees were inflated, auditors and regulators would not allow them. Related-party transactions,  value extraction — they exist in almost every demerged structure. 3 The tech wasn’t given away, Ingenuity was moved so it could be valued, sold, or partnered independently. That’s exactly what investors had been demanding for years. THG still has full contractual access — nothing was lost. 4 Debt staying with RemainCo is normal in demergers Debt follows cash-generating businesses (Nutrition & Beauty). That’s standard corporate finance, not a dump. Bottom line: There is zero evidence of theft, only a standard demerger structure that the market may or may not like.  If this were a screw job, it would not have been signed off on by the auditors, regulators, banks, and major shareholders. Without actual proof, this is noise with an agenda. The share price is being manipulated of that there is no doubt. Everybody knows it.

data.content: PROOF #4: The "Headcount" Shuffle The Document: THG Annual Report (Strategic Report Section - People). The Test: Are you paying for ghost workers? Look at the "Average number of employees" note. The Trend: You will likely see the headcount at THG Public drop significantly (as tech/warehouse staff moved to Ingenuity). The "Screw Job": Even though the staff are gone, the "Distribution Costs" line item on the Income Statement didn't drop by the same amount. Instead, the cost just changed names from "Wages" to "Service Fees." You are paying the same (or more) for staff you no longer employ or control. Summary: The Single Chart to Look For If you only look at one thing, find the "Segmental Adjusted EBITDA" chart in the H1 2025 presentation. Visual Proof: You will see a bar for THG Nutrition that is tiny compared to 2 years ago. Ask yourself: "Did people stop eating protein?" No (see Applied Nutrition). "Did the warehouse get more expensive?" Yes.

data.author: cantbelieveit
data.content: You don't have to trust me, and you don't have to trust Matthew Moulding. You can see the "screw job" yourself by looking at three specific public documents. Here is your "Do It Yourself" Audit Kit to prove THG Public (You) is being drained by Ingenuity Private (Moulding). PROOF #1: The "Same Ingredients, Different Profit" Test The Document: THG Interim Results H1 2025 (Released Sept 2025) vs. Applied Nutrition FY25 Results (Released Nov 2025). The Test: Both companies buy the exact same raw material (Whey Protein). Both sell to the same customers. Go to THG’s H1 2025 Report: Look for the Segmental Breakdown table. Find: THG Nutrition Adjusted EBITDA Margin. The Number: You will see it collapsed to ~3.9%. (Management blamed "high whey prices"). Go to Applied Nutrition’s FY25 Report: Look for the Financial Highlights page. Find: EBITDA Margin. The Number: You will see it sits at ~30%. The Conclusion: If "high whey prices" were the real problem, Applied Nutrition would have crashed too. They didn't. The ~26% difference is almost entirely the "Ingenuity Tax"—the inflated fees THG Nutrition is forced to pay for warehousing and tech. PROOF #2: The "Related Party" Leak The Document: THG Demerger Circular (Published Nov 2024) or the H1 2025 Financial Statements. The Test: Find the money leaving the building. Go to the "Related Party Transactions" Note: This is usually Note 18 or similar in the back of the accounts. Find: "Amounts payable to THG Ingenuity." The Number: In 2024/2025, this figure runs into the hundreds of millions. The "Kick in the Teeth": Look for the "Master Services Agreement (MSA)" terms in the Demerger Circular. It explicitly states the contract is for 10 years. This proves you are legally locked into paying these fees until ~2035, regardless of whether you make a profit. PROOF #3: The "Debt Dump" The Document: THG H1 2025 Balance Sheet. The Test: Who kept the mortgage, and who got the house? Look at "Net Debt": You will see THG Public (RemainCo) holds roughly £321 million in net debt. Look at "Intangible Assets": You will see a massive drop because the proprietary technology (the "Ingenuity Platform" IP) was transferred to the Private Company. The Conclusion: The Public Company kept the debt (the burden) but gave away the tech assets (the potential growth). You are now paying rent to use the technology you used to own, while still paying off the bank loans used to build it.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: This is what MM said - he is open to selling assets, and I think he will. Look, as you would expect, since we’ve announced the sale of Claremont, there’s obviously a lot of interest in the background as to some of our other manufacturing assets in particular and the performances of that. It would be fair to say we’ve had formal approaches on some of those assets. We’re pretty clear as to how we stand on these things, which is the private market valuations, as we saw with Claremont, are robust. If we receive interest in an asset where we believe we can make a deal work for us without in any way negatively impacting the existing business models of either nutrition or beauty, then sure, we will entertain that and know and derive a fair valuation for one of those assets, especially if it’s of a material value. If it’s something that’s like with Claremont, it was £100 million plus consideration, then sure, we would do that, especially given the valuations that are on, you know, of THG and the wider PLC market today. I think that’s probably as deep as I should go into that. I think we’ve been pretty frank and open to say, look, we could quite readily put an RNS out at any point to say we’ve done a transaction. It would be something that’s relatively non-core at a fair market value that delivers something that we’re pretty pleased with. How long will that be before we do that? Who knows? It will depend on achieving the right price points, if those prices arrive. That’s probably as much as I can say right now.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Am with John Gould on how undervalued THG is; let's not forget what he said a few months ago Coke has a market cap of £211bn and small net debt with £35bn of sales giving an EV/Sales of 6.6x. Coke backed Monster ten years ago with a $2bn investment for a 17% holding. That $2bn represented less than 1% of Coke’s value. Monster has revenues of £5.6bn, a market cap of £48.1bn with small debt giving an EV/Sales of 8.6x. Monster’s share price is up 40x over 20 years. Coke’s $2bn investment is now worth around $8bn, driven by Monster’s push through Coke’s distribution network. Celsius, the US-listed health drink, offers a similar story. Pepsi is an 11% shareholder and global distribution partner. Pepsi bought into Celsius in 2022 and in August 2025 with another $500m. Pepsi has invested over $1bn for its 11% stake which is less than 1% of its mkt cap. Celsius’s mkt cap is £11.1bn with revenue of £1.0bn last year being an 11x sales multiple. Its share price is up c.30x in just five years. Lotus Bakeries, the Dutch-listed food business behind Lotus Biscoff, shows that you don’t need to be Coke-sized to achieve strong valuations. Its health division includes Trek and Nak’d bars, both acquired over the past five years. Lotus has a mkt cap of £5.7bn with small debt with £1.1bn revenue in 2024 and trades on an EV/Sales of 5.4x. Fevertree, a UK stock partnered with Molson in January 2025 which invested £70m for an 8.5% stake (around 1% of Molson’s mkt cap). Fevertree has sales of £360m last year and a mkt cap of £1bn, giving EV/Sales of 2.7x. Molson has the capability to significantly accelerate Fevertree’s growth. As for THG, its mkt cap is £540m with £200m net debt, giving an EV of £740m. Total sales post-demerger last year were £1.7bn, of which £580m came from THG Nutrition (MyProtein) and the balance from THG Beauty. If we split value 50/50, MyProtein trades on c. 0.6x sales. MyProtein appears to be on the radar screen of several global brands such as Muller and the new unnamed global confectioner who appear to want to work with them on product development.

data.content: This will be great for THG The World Cup is great for THG (The Hut Group) and Myprotein through increased sales from global sports nutrition demand, driving revenue, brand awareness, and new market entry, especially with partnerships like Hyrox and Mars, showing consumers prioritize wellness, while Myprotein leverages quality and innovation, like animal-free whey, to meet this demand for effective protein supplements for athletes and fitness enthusiasts. How the World Cup (and major sports events) benefits THG/Myprotein: Increased Sales: Major tournaments boost global interest in fitness and nutrition, leading more people to buy protein supplements and related products for muscle recovery and performance. Market Expansion: Partnerships and increased visibility during big events help Myprotein reach wider audiences in new markets, says City AM. Brand Recognition: Being associated with elite sports elevates Myprotein's brand as a go-to for serious athletes and fitness fans. Product Innovation: Demand encourages development of new products, like their animal-free whey, catering to different dietary needs and sustainability concerns, notes Perfect Day. Myprotein's Role & Products: Quality & Differentiation: City AM notes Myprotein differentiates itself with quality, good pricing, and innovative products like protein pancakes and diet whey. Athlete Support: Products like Impact Whey provide essential amino acids (EAAs) and branched-chain amino acids (BCAAs) for muscle repair and growth. Convenience: Products like protein pancake mixes and convenient shakes offer easy ways to meet protein goals. In essence, the global excitement around the World Cup fuels the health and wellness trend, directly benefiting companies like THG and its Myprotein brand by increasing demand for their high-quality, innovative protein solutions.

data.title: Myprotein licensing partnership with Greencore
data.full_content:
Today 07:00
RNS Number : 6729S
THG PLC
12 February 2026
12
February 2026
THG PLC
Myprotein seals new licensing partnership with Greencore for protein-rich convenience foods
Myprotein, the world's leading online sports nutrition brand, today announces a strategic partnership with Greencore, a leading producer of convenience foods. The collaboration will introduce a new range of Myprotein branded food on-the-go items, significantly expanding the brand's presence in offline retail channels and continuing its successful 6 aisle strategy of launching new licensing agreements with best-in-class partners.
The range will include protein-enriched salads and wraps, with scope to expand into other profiles and formats, helping consumers access convenient, nutritious meals that align with their fitness and healthy lifestyle goals. These products will be available in Sainsbury's supermarkets and convenience stores.
The Greencore partnership forms part of Myprotein's wider strategic ambition to grow its offline and licensing footprint to 100,000 doors, allowing for deeper penetration with existing retail partners and accelerated expansion within the convenience channel. Food-to-go represents a high-frequency, high-visibility consumption occasion that complements Myprotein's existing protein portfolio, covering powders, dairy and desserts, bars and snacks and ready-to-drink, broadening consumer touchpoints beyond the gym and home.
Licensing agreements with category leaders including Müller, Iceland and Jimmy's Coffee, led to sales of over 43 million Myprotein units into retail during 2025. This strategy leverages its global brand recognition alongside specialised manufacturing and distribution expertise.
Neil Mistry, CEO of THG Nutrition, commented:
"This collaboration is another step in Myprotein's global leadership across sports nutrition, adding Greencore's expertise in creating and distributing fresh, on-the-go food to our growing list of partners.
"The range builds on the demand of GLP-1 consumers, along with trends towards cleaner nutrition combined with protein-rich foods and snacks. This partnership not only widens the reach of the Myprotein brand offering, it brings further significant penetration into offline channels.
"Following a strong start to the year across our licensed ranges, we expect to significantly build on last year's performance, with the brand on target to sell-in over 60 million licensed products in 2026, up from 43 million in 2025."
Andy Parton, Chief Commercial Officer of Greencore, commented:
"We're thrilled to partner with Myprotein to bring high
‑
quality, protein
‑
rich food
‑
to
‑
go options to consumers across the UK. As demand grows for convenient, nutritious products that support healthier lifestyles, this collaboration allows us to combine Greencore's expertise in fresh, ready
‑
to

eat food with one of the most recognisable brands in sports nutrition. We're excited about the potential of this partnership and look forward to expanding the range together."

THG PLC is a global e-commerce group and brand owner headquartered in Manchester, UK, which operates through two leading consumer businesses: THG Beauty and THG Nutrition.
THG Beauty operates prominent online platforms including Lookfantastic, Dermstore and Cult Beauty, offering a valued route to market for over 1,000 third-party brands, alongside a specialist portfolio of owned brands.
THG Nutrition, led by Myprotein, the world's largest online sports nutrition brand, spans multiple health and wellness categories, delivering its products both directly to consumers and through strategic offline partnerships worldwide.

data.author: stanleyb
data.content: JFYI The CEO of a FTSE 250 company is not allowed to issue misleading information to the market. Doing so is illegal and constitutes a serious breach of UK financial regulations, potentially leading to severe criminal and civil penalties. Listed companies and their officers (including CEOs) are subject to stringent regulations overseen by the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA), designed to ensure market integrity and transparency. Such actions constitute market abuse and can lead to severe penalties, including imprisonment for the CEO and massive fines for the company. Here is a breakdown of the regulations and consequences based on the Market Abuse Regulation (MAR) and the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (FSMA): 1. The Legal and Regulatory Framework Market Abuse Regulation (MAR): Under MAR, it is illegal to disclose inside information unlawfully or engage in market manipulation. FCA Rules (Disclosure and Transparency Rules - DTR): Listed companies must ensure that any information released is not misleading, false, or deceptive. FSMA Section 397: It is a criminal offence to knowingly or recklessly make a statement, promise, or forecast that is materially misleading, false, or deceptive, or to dishonestly conceal material facts. Section 90A FSMA: This allows investors to claim for losses if they relied on misleading information published to the market. RNS issued by THG 17th September 2024 https://www.lse.co.uk/rns/escc-transfer-ingenuity-demerger-update-11s0rr0th1uzg9o.html 1. Highly Profitable (The "Paper" Success) ​Profitability is an accounting metric. It’s what is left over after you subtract expenses from revenue. When a company is "highly profitable," its margins are excellent—it earns a lot of money for every dollar it spends. ​2. Cash Generative (The "Wallet" Success) ​Cash generation (often called Free Cash Flow) refers to the actual physical money moving into the company’s bank account. A "cash generative" business is one that consistently produces more liquid cash than it spends to keep the doors open. So no concerns then as according to the RNS.. "...Post a demerger, the Group would consist of THG Beauty and THG Nutrition, two globally leading consumer businesses, which are highly profitable, cash generative and capable of paying dividends....." data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Historically, the Yen has bounced as much as 30% when the carry trades unwound: During the 2008 Global Financial Crisis, the Japanese yen surged sharply as the global carry trade collapsed. For years, investors had borrowed cheaply in yen—thanks to near-zero rates from the Bank of Japan—and invested in higher-yielding assets abroad. When the crisis intensified and Lehman Brothers failed in September 2008, markets froze, leverage was unwound, and investors were forced to buy back yen to repay loans. This triggered a powerful short squeeze: USD/JPY fell from around 124 in 2007 to about 87 by late 2008 (roughly a 30% yen appreciation), while high-beta crosses like AUD/JPY collapsed nearly 50%. The move was amplified by global deleveraging, margin calls, and Japan’s status as a net creditor nation, which encouraged capital repatriation and reinforced the yen’s rise.

data.content: Do you mean this conference call stan: Summary of THG Q4 Earnings Call THG Holdings PLC delivered a strong Q4 and ended 2025 with clear momentum, marking its first full year of revenue growth since 2021 despite a challenging macro backdrop. Strong Return to Growth * Q4 revenue grew 7%, driven by a very strong second half. * H2 performance came in **14% ahead of the top end of guidance, highlighting improving execution. * Growth was broad-based across core divisions. Beauty Performing Exceptionally Well * THG Beauty grew 6.4% in Q4, well ahead of expectations. * Lookfantastic UK & Ireland delivered **16.2% growth**, supported by: * Record customer retention * Growing loyalty membership * Higher spend per customer * Management highlighted strong momentum in devices, apps, loyalty schemes and social-driven beauty trends (including TikTok influence). Offline beauty is also proving successful: * The first Lookfantastic store in Altrincham has traded significantly ahead of expectations. * The store is profitable **and** delivering a measurable online “halo effect”. * Additional stores are planned, using a disciplined, brand-partnered rollout strategy. Nutrition Continues to Grow * THG Nutrition grew 8.5% in Q4. * Myprotein remains the world’s number one sports nutrition brand. * Offline expansion continues, with new U.S. listings at major retailers including GNC and Kroger launching in H1 2026. While whey prices remain elevated, management stressed: * Global protein demand is at record levels * Commodity cycles are temporary * The long-term market opportunity has significantly expanded High-margin categories such as activewear are growing strongly and are expected to exceed **15% of Myprotein revenue mix in 2026**. Business Simplification Largely Complete * Portfolio optimisation in beauty (exiting lower-return regions) is now largely annualised. * Non-core asset disposals and operational streamlining are complete. * This sets up **cleaner comparisons and improved efficiency** going into 2026. Confident Outlook for 2026 Management repeatedly emphasized confidence in trading momentum: * Expected **FY26 EBITDA around £100m** * Forecast **£20–25m of free cash flow** * Continued investment in marketing to support sustainable long-term growth * Increased use of AI and personalization tools across beauty CEO Matthew Moulding stated the group enters 2026 with significant momentum and a stronger, more focused operating model. VAT Upside Optionality * THG is awaiting the outcome of HMRC’s final appeal attempt. * Potential VAT repayment has grown to approximately £55m. * Management has taken a prudent approach, continuing to pay VAT while the case concludes. * Any successful outcome would represent a material cash inflow for the group.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Protein powders are not automatically HSA/FSA-eligible under normal IRS rules. My earlier wording made it sound like they’re universally covered, which isn’t accurate. What’s actually happening with the Myprotein + Flex partnership is this: Standard IRS rules only allow HSA/FSA spending on items that treat or prevent a specific medical condition. General “wellness” protein or supplements for fitness don’t qualify by default. Platforms like Flex/TrueMed work by: Screening the customer with a short health questionnaire Determining whether the product is being used for a medical purpose (e.g., obesity management, malnutrition, recovery, doctor-recommended use) Generating the required documentation/Letter of Medical Necessity Then enabling HSA/FSA payment at checkout when it meets those criteria. So it’s new in the sense that:

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Don't trust AI, on further inspection, it looks like protein powders may not be included

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: OK so I have no clue what an FSA or HSA is so I googled it: HSA (Health Savings Account) and FSA (Flexible Spending Account) are U.S. schemes that let people pay for health-related products with pre-tax dollars, effectively giving a 20–40% saving depending on tax bracket. An HSA is linked to a high-deductible health plan and the money belongs to the individual forever, rolling over year to year and even earning investment growth. An FSA is provided by employers, also tax-free, but usually must be used within the year with limited rollover. Both can be used for eligible medical and wellness items, and with partners like Flex they can now cover products such as protein powders and creatine, making those purchases significantly cheaper for U.S. consumers.

data.author: gggg21
data.content: Potentially tapped a larger market in USA now as spend can be at myprotein in US A Flexible Spending Account (FSA) in the USA is an employer-sponsored, tax-advantaged account that allows employees to set aside a portion of their earnings to pay for eligible medical, dental, vision, or dependent care expenses. Because the money is deducted from paychecks before taxes are taken out, it lowers taxable income, typically resulting in a savings of about 30% on eligible expenses. Key Types of FSAs Health Care FSA (HCFSA): Used for qualified medical, dental, and vision expenses, such as copayments, deductibles, prescription drugs, and medical devices (e.g., crutches, blood sugar test kits). Limited Expense Health Care FSA (LEX HCFSA): Designed for those with a High Deductible Health Plan (HDHP) and a Health Savings Account (HSA). It only covers dental and vision expenses, helping preserve HSA funds. Dependent Care FSA (DCFSA): Used to pay for qualified out-of-pocket dependent care expenses, such as preschool, summer day camp, before/after-school programs, and child/adult daycare, allowing employees to work. Rules and Limitations Contribution Limits (2026): For 2026, the maximum contribution to a health care FSA is $3,400 per year. The maximum for a dependent care FSA is $7,500 per household, or $3,750 if married and filing separately. "Use-It-or-Lose-It": Unused funds are generally forfeited to the employer at the end of the plan year.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Did a bit of digging and this could be big - there are a large number of Americans who already use HSAs, meaning there’s a big potential customer base who can now buy products with tax-free dollars. As of the end of 2024, over 59 million Americans are covered by an HSA, with around 39 million individual HSA accounts in use — and that number has been growing steadily year-on-year. That means a substantial audience with pre-tax spending power on health and wellness products, which can boost repeat purchases and increase average order size for Myprotein. More people being able to use their HSA dollars for protein, creatine and other nutrition stacks could translate into meaningful sales growth.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: S74 ou’re right on the distinction between FCF and accounting profit, but the two are now converging. Analysts are forecasting EBITDA moving toward ~£100m in 2026, and with interest costs falling after the refinancing and Claremont proceeds, that bridge to positive PAT is getting much shorter. It’s not just disposals doing the work – core revenue and margins are improving. FCF turning positive is the first step; lower debt then converts more of that into net profit. That’s why many expect 2026, not 2028, to be the year THG moves onto a P/E valuation. Remember, these analysts' predictions do not include the £60M VAT potential windfall or another asset sale. If just one of them comes in, then they will shift up significantly.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Rock, I don’t think that’s realistic. This wasn’t just an internal “transfer pricing” exercise done in a back room – the demerger was a major corporate transaction with lenders, auditors and institutional shareholders all having a direct financial interest in the outcome. The banks refinancing THG wouldn’t have signed off contracts that left remainco carrying uncommercial terms, and the auditors have to be comfortable that related-party arrangements are on arm’s-length terms. Large shareholders didn’t just shrug and hope for the best either. They had every incentive to challenge anything that disadvantaged THG remainco, because they’re the ones whose value would be destroyed if the contracts were unfair. The idea that the business was carved up with no meaningful scrutiny doesn’t stack up with how these processes actually work in listed companies. Could the terms have been negotiated harder? Maybe – but to suggest they’re obviously “bad deals” assumes everyone involved ignored their own interests, which seems far less likely than the contracts being broadly commercial and workable for both sides.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Monty, I totally get your point about looking at PAT vs debt — that’s exactly why the THG picture is improving. Net debt has already been coming down materially. The recent Claremont sale alone brought in around £100m+ in cash, with proceeds directed to further deleveraging. On top of the earlier refinancing and disposals, THG has taken hundreds of millions off gross debt over the last 18 months, which directly reduces interest costs and improves the PAT outlook. That’s why analysts are now pointing to 2026 as the year THG reports its first genuine net profit. Lower finance charges + improving EBITDA from Nutrition and Beauty = PAT finally turning positive. This isn’t “window dressing,” it’s basic mechanics: less debt = less interest = more profit flowing to the bottom line. Also worth remembering THG still has significant assets. We know there is a lot of interest in many of these assets. Another strategic sale or minority stake in one of the premium brands could realistically wipe the debt altogether. If that happened, PAT would step up sharply because the interest burden would almost disappear. So when you talk about a sensible debt/PAT ratio, that’s exactly the path that THG is on — deleveraging first, profitability second. Calling that gambling ignores the actual balance-sheet progress that’s already happened. I get the point about looking at PAT vs debt — that’s exactly why the THG picture is improving. But you already know this, don't you Monty? What will you be saying in 2027 - THG is not making ENOUGH profit Then in 2028 - THG's dividends are not BIG ENOUGH I see through you Monty - hopefully others on here will too :)

data.author: stanleyb
data.content: This is what an AI engine thinks of any Potential partnership deal between THG and Greggs if it were to happen..quite interesting read. JAO 😳 😳 Here is why a THG (Myprotein) x Greggs partnership would—theoretically—be a brilliant financial move for both: ​1. The "Health-Halo" for Greggs ​Greggs is currently desperate to prove it isn't just a "sausage roll peddler." ​The Problem: Their "Balanced Choice" range has been around for years, but it lacks "street cred" with the fitness crowd. ​The Solution: A Myprotein-branded "Power Meal Deal" at Greggs would give them instant authority. Imagine a "Myprotein x Greggs" Chicken & Pesto Pasta or a high-protein breakfast pot. It would turn a "guilty pleasure" destination into a legitimate choice for the 14% of UK consumers currently trying to increase protein intake. ​2. Physical Footprint for THG ​THG has roughly 2,700 "doors" via its recent Sainsbury’s/Greencore deal. ​The Scale: Greggs has over 2,740 shops and is aiming for 3,000. ​The Advantage: A Greggs partnership would effectively double Myprotein’s physical presence overnight. More importantly, it puts Myprotein in high-footfall "grab-and-go" locations (train stations, high streets, and petrol stations) where people are looking for a quick, healthy alternative to a pasty. ​3. Fighting the "GLP-1" Decline ​Greggs' CEO, Roisin Currie, admitted in late 2025 that appetite-suppressing drugs are a "market headwind." ​People on these medications eat less, but when they do eat, they prioritize nutrient density (protein/fibre) to avoid muscle loss. ​By partnering with Myprotein, Greggs could capture the "reduced-appetite" spender who is currently walking past their store to go to an M&S Foodhall or a Joe & The Juice. ​Is it actually likely? ​While it makes financial sense, there are two major hurdles: ​The Brand Conflict: Greggs has spent 10 years building its own "Balanced Choice" brand. Admitting they need Myprotein's help might be seen as a sign of weakness by their own marketing team. ​The Greencore Exclusive: It’s possible that THG’s new deal with Greencore (who also supplies many of the UK's top retailers) might have "exclusivity clauses" that prevent Myprotein from doing a direct manufacturing deal with a competitor like Greggs for a set period. ​Summary: The "Bull Case" for the Share Price ​If Matt Moulding announced a Greggs x Myprotein partnership, the share price would almost certainly re-test that 51p level or higher. It would be seen as the ultimate "mainstreaming" of the brand. JAO ADYOR!

data.content: Reminder of MyProtein offline stats from q3 transcript - food on the go defo has the opportunity to grow and be as good as the Iceland £70M partnership: Q3 Transcript: All right, in terms of answering the nutrition question on how much extra. Product is out there. How much, I think, look, to give you a small fact on that, the Müller as an example had the selling to retailers in Müller. Now I think we’re on our third month of 2 million Myprotein units. Into retail in a month for three consecutive months. I know it’s certainly two. I’m expecting the third month when I see the data to come through with the same as well. The sellout is a bit different, but obviously we’re interested in the selling just as much,were 2 million units just in protein. Yogurts under the Müller partnership. That gives you an idea of the extent of the touch points that we have in that. If you were to look at Iceland as a retailer, we’re probably doing in the region of about £70 million a year of frozen meals with Iceland across two different types of ranges that we have with them. Now the average meal is somewhere in the region of about £3.50. I think given all the average product, there are some cheaper products than that they sell. You get an idea there. There’s, you know, £20 million of products probably going out the door just in frozen foods and that’s pretty much limited to Iceland. There are some other distribution points, but it’s very successful for them. They do control distribution of that and they do have an exclusive on that range of products in there.

data.author: Craftyinvestor
data.content: Positive feedback on the partnership 1. A powerful strategic fit Greencore Group plc is one of the UK’s and Ireland’s largest convenience food producers — supplying sandwiches, wraps, ready meals and other chilled products. It’s also the largest sandwich manufacturer in the world. So partnering with them gives Myprotein instant credibility and best-in-class manufacturing, distribution and category expertise. For Greencore, working with the UK’s biggest sports nutrition brand positions them at the heart of the high-growth, high-protein convenience market rather than just traditional sandwiches. 2. Major retail validation Launching in 500+ Sainsbury’s stores and inside the meal deal space is a huge achievement. Meal deals drive some of the highest footfall and repeat purchase in UK grocery — this puts Myprotein in front of millions of mainstream consumers, not just gym enthusiasts. 3. Category expansion done the right way Moving from powders and supplements into fresh, ready-to-eat food is a bold step. Doing it via Greencore shows a smart, asset-light strategy: leverage an expert partner instead of building complex chilled manufacturing in-house. 4. Products that match consumer trends Up to 28g protein, <376 calories, strong flavours like Firecracker and Teriyaki — this hits exactly what shoppers want: Healthier Convenience, High protein,Great taste with no “diet food” compromise Perfect for the growing audience of hybrid workers and time-poor consumers. 5. Growth runway for both sides The post confirms this is just phase one, with broader UK distribution planned later in the year. That gives Greencore: incremental volumes,higher-value branded production, deeper relationship with THG/Myprotein And gives Myprotein a bridge from online dominance into offline everyday consumption.. Well done, THG this is a great deal

data.author: sparsam
data.content: Ok and here are all your points with a bearish view. THG Q4 Earnings Call “Strong Return to Growth” – Or Just Easy Comparatives? •	The 7% Q4 growth is viewed by critics as largely a function of easy prior-year comparisons, following multiple years of contraction rather than a true acceleration. •	Forum users note that management has repeatedly talked up “strong H2 momentum” in previous years, only for growth to fade again. •	The claim that H2 came 14% ahead of guidance is treated with scepticism, as THG has a long history of guidance resets, lowered bars, and selective framing. •	“Broad-based growth” is questioned, with bears arguing that growth is uneven and still dependent on promotions and discounting, not organic demand strength. ⸻ Beauty “Exceptional” – But at What Cost? •	The 6.4% Q4 beauty growth is seen as underwhelming relative to the amount of marketing spend and discounting required to achieve it. •	Critics on LSE highlight that growth in Lookfantastic UK & Ireland (+16.2%) likely reflects: •	Heavy promotional activity •	Loyalty incentives that compress margins •	Pull-forward demand rather than sustainable expansion •	Record retention and higher spend per customer are viewed cautiously, with posters noting: •	Loyalty schemes often mask churn by subsidising repeat purchases •	Increased spend may be inflation-driven, not volume-led •	TikTok and social-driven trends are considered highly fickle, with little moat and rapid reversals in consumer behaviour. ⸻ Offline Beauty Stores – High Risk, Low Proof •	The Altrincham store being “ahead of expectations” is dismissed by sceptics as: •	A single data point •	Located in an affluent catchment area unlikely to be representative •	Profitability claims are questioned due to: •	Lack of disclosed store-level economics •	No clarity on rent, staffing, or capex assumptions •	The so-called “halo effect” is viewed as unquantified marketing spin, something THG has frequently cited without hard evidence. •	Bears argue store expansion introduces: •	Fixed costs •	Execution risk •	A move away from the asset-light e-commerce model THG once sold investors ⸻ Nutrition Growth – Margin Pressure Still the Elephant in the Room •	8.5% Q4 growth in Nutrition is viewed as modest given the category’s historical growth rates. •	Claims of Myprotein being the “world’s number one” brand are criticised as: •	Marketing language without independently verifiable metrics •	US retail listings (GNC, Kroger) are seen as: •	Lower-margin wholesale channels •	Likely to dilute brand positioning and profitability •	Elevated whey prices are not dismissed as “temporary” by critics, who argue: •	Structural protein demand + geopolitics = permanently higher input costs •	THG lacks sufficient pricing power to fully pass these through •	Activewear growth is viewed as: •	A crowded, low-loyalty category •	Historically poor margin territory for DTC bran
